title: XSS via Mod Log Removed Posts
content:
Summary:
I have discovered an XSS vulnerability regarding the mod notes feature. Specifically, the XSS payload executes when the victim removes a post in a subreddit and opens up the mod notes of the attacker.
Steps To Reproduce:
The attacker creates a new post with the title containing the XSS payload.
The victim (mods of the subreddit) then must remove your post.
The payload executes when a victim (subreddit mod) opens up your mod notes. Sometimes, the mod notes are displayed when the victim hovers on your profile (this is true when a recent mod action has been taken on the user).

steps: The attacker creates a new post with a title containing an XSS payload.
The victim (subreddit moderator) removes the attacker's post, triggering the XSS payload when viewing the attacker's mod notes.
vuln_description: An XSS vulnerability exists in the mod notes feature where a malicious payload embedded in a post's title executes when a moderator removes the post and views the attacker's mod notes. The payload may also execute when hovering over the attacker's profile if recent mod actions have been taken.
reason: The vulnerability involves understanding the interaction between post removal and mod notes display, but the attack chain is relatively straightforward once the XSS vector is identified. The components (post creation, removal, mod notes) are standard features with predictable interactions.

authnz_metadata.reason: The XSS vulnerability involves mod notes and post removal actions, which are scoped within the same application (Reddit). The methodology involves testing actions with different user sessions and resource IDs, which could potentially detect this if the mod notes action is logged and tested with swapped sessions or resource IDs.

injection_metadata.reasoning: The XSS vulnerability involves injecting a payload into a post title (an injectable parameter) which triggers when mod notes are viewed. The methodology would detect this because: 1) Title parameters would be logged as injectable during regular navigation, 2) Simple payloads could be tested in titles without filter bypasses, and 3) Execution verification occurs through same-channel navigation (mods viewing mod notes via regular UI interactions). Though the trigger requires a specific mod action (post removal), the methodology accounts for stored XSS scenarios where payloads manifest in different UI elements accessible through normal user workflows.
